questions.text: Foot drop along with loss of eversion is caused by damage to:
questions.solution:
Foot drop with loss of eversion is caused by damage to the common peroneal nerve.

The common peroneal nerve is a component of the sciatic nerve. In the posterior thigh, it supplies the short head of biceps femoris. It curves around the neck of fibula deep to peroneus longus and divides into superficial and deep peroneal nerves.

  • The superficial peroneal nerve innervates peroneus longus and peroneus brevis which are the evertors of foot and to the skin over dorsal area of foot except the first webspace and lateral side of little toe.
  • The deep peroneal nerve innervates all muscles of anterior compartment which are the dorsiflexors of foot, extensor digitorum brevis, first two dorsal interossei muscles and skin between great and second toes.

Common peroneal nerve is closely related to neck of the fibula and hence the nerve is commonly injured in fracture involving this area.

Injury to common peroneal nerve will lead to:

  • Weakness of dorsiflexion of foot or foot drop
  • Loss of eversion
  • Loss of extension of toes
  • Sensory loss along the anterior and lateral side of the leg, dorsum of foot including the medial side of great toe.

Note: Injury to the deep peroneal nerve will cause foot drop with intact eversion.

questions.text: A patient with parathyroid deficiency, 10 days after inadvertent damage to the parathyroid glands during thyroid surgery would probably have:

choices.text: High plasma phosphate, High Ca2+ levels and tetanus.
Low plasma Ca2+ level, tetany, and Trousseau sign.
Low plasma phosphate and high Ca2+ levels and bone demineralization.
Increased muscular excitability, a high plasma Ca2+ level, and bone demineralization

questions.solution:
Parathyroid hormone deficiency leads to low Ca+2 level, tetany and Trousseau sign.

(Please differentiate with tetanus which is caused by infection with the bacteria Clostridium tetani)

Actions of PTH include

  • PTH stimulates bone resorption, causing the release of calcium into the extracel­lular fluid;
  • PTH increases reabsorption of calcium and decreases phosphate reabsorption by the renal tubules, leading to reduced excretion of calcium and increased excretion of phosphate; and
  • PTH is necessary for the conversion of 25­-hydroxycholecalciferol to 1,25­ dihydroxycholecalciferol, which, in turn, increases calcium absorption by the intestines. 

So, a deficiency of PTH would lead to low Ca+2 levels and high Phosphate levels. 

Symptoms and signs of hypocalcemia - mild circumoral or digital numbness and paresthesia, carpopedal spasm, or laryngeal spasms and cardiac arrhythmias. Chvostek and Trousseaus sign may be elicited. ECG changes may show QT prolongation or QRS changes.

The signs of tetany in humans include Chvostek sign, a quick contraction of the ipsilateral facial muscles elicited by tapping over the facial nerve at the angle of the jaw, and Trousseau sign, a spasm of the muscles of the upper extremity that causes flexion of the wrist and thumb.

Management - Acute symptomatic hypocalcemia is an emergency and must be treated with IV and oral calcium and vitamin D replacement. 10 ml IV calcium gluconate 10% is given slowly. Supplemental Magnesium may also be required due to the synergestic actions of calcium and magnesium. 

A hand being held similarly to Trousseau's sign (below).

Related Pearl: Summary of hormones that regulate Ca2+ levels

questions.text: In which of the following tissues does gluconeogenesis take place?
questions.solution:
Liver and kidney are the two major locations where gluconeogenesis takes place.

During short periods of fasting, most of gluconeogenesis takes place in the liver, while the remaining takes place in the kidneys. However, during periods of prolonged fasting, the kidneys become a major site of gluconeogenesis.

Gluconeogenesis:

  • Gluconeogenesis is the process of synthesizing glucose or glycogen from non-carbohydrate precursors.
  • Gluconeogenesis occurs in cytosol and mitochondria of the liver and kidney.
  • Significant substrates are glucogenic amino acids, lactate, glycerol, and propionate.
  • Lactate generated in various tissues is transported to the liver and is converted to back to pyruvate and enters gluconeogenesis. This pathway is referred to as Cori’s cycle.
  • Glucose-alanine cycle is referred to as Cahill cycle.
  • Muscle cannot participate in gluconeogenesis since it lacks glucose-6-phosphatase.

questions.text: A patient with a history of peptic ulcer underwent upper GI endoscopic biopsy of the stomach. The biopsy is stained with a special stain and shown in the image. What is the special stain used?
questions.solution:
The given slide shows the GI mucosa, which has been stained with Warthin-Starry silver stain, demonstrating the bacilli (Helicobacter pylori) causing type B gastritis.

On antral biopsy, H. pylori organisms are seen abundantly within the surface mucus layer, but they are difficult to visualize with routine hematoxylin (H&E) stains. Organisms are most easily demonstrated with special stains like Warthin starry silver stain or Giemsa stain.

Type B gastritis 

  • Type B gastritis is associated with H. pylori.
  • It commonly affects the antrum.
  • Intestinal metaplasia is associated with chronic pan-gastritis with atrophy.
  • Intestinal metaplasia with dysplasia has malignant potential.

H. pylori infection is also a risk factor for the following:

  • Peptic ulcer disease (duodenal > gastric)
  • Gastric adenocarcinoma
  • Gastric lymphoma

Image: Warthin-Starry silver stain showing Helicobacter pylori colonized on the surface of the regenerative epithelium.

Image: Giemsa stain showing Helicobacter pylori in a case of chronic gastritis.

Related Pearl: Various stains and their applications in Pathology and Microbiology

Staining technique Uses

Perl's Prussian blue Demonstrate hemosiderin and iron
Masson–Fontana stain Demonstrate melanin in nevus and malignant melanoma
von Kossa method Demonstrate calcium
Van Gieson stain

Demonstrate collagen in spindle-cell neoplasm; Delineate extent of fibrosis; Differentiate amyloid from collagen
Masson trichrome stain Demonstrate collagen and muscle in connective tissue disorders, muscle and fibroblast tumors, liver cirrhosis, neuromuscular diseases
Reticulin stain Demonstrate reticulin fibers to distinguish epithelial from non-epithelial neoplasm, Hodgkin's lymphoma, early cirrhosis of the liver, myelofibrosis
Verhoeff's method Demonstrate elastic fibers in malignant hypertension, arteriovenous malformation aneurysms, Marfan's syndrome, emphysema lung
Oil red O Sudan Black Sudan III/IV Demonstrate fat/lipids: Fatty liver-fat embolism-fibroma vs. thecoma of the ovary-liposarcoma

questions.text: Which of the following parasites may cause deficiency of vitamin B12?
questions.solution:
Diphyllobothrium latum causes deficiency of vitamin B12

The anemia develops because the tapeworm absorbs a large quantity of Vitamin B12 and interferes with its ileal absorption leading to Vitamin B12 deficiency. In severe cases, patients may exhibit neurologic sequelae of vitamin B12 deficiency.

Diphyllobothrium latum is also known as Fish tapeworm or Broad tapeworm.

  • The first intermediate host is freshwater crustacean, while the second intermediate host is freshwater fish.
  • The definitive hosts are man, dog, and cat.

The infective form to humans is the third stage plerocercoid larvae. It possesses a rudimentary scolex. The adult worm lives inside the small intestine and lays operculated eggs. These freshly passed eggs contain an immature embryo surrounded by yolk granules. This hexacanth embryo with 6 hooklets inside the egg is called Oncosphere.

 

Related Pearl: Infective form and diagnostic forms - Worms

TREMATODE

Other trematodes - Fasciola hepatica, Fasciolopsis buski, Paragonimus westermani, Clonorchis sinensis Metacercaria larva Operculated Eggs

HINT: The infective and diagnostic forms are usually the same in the parasites causing AUTOINFECTION.

questions.text: Which of the following is used in first line management of postmenopausal osteoporosis:
questions.solution:
Bisphosphonates are used in the first-line management of postmenopausal osteoporosis.

Mechanism of action :-

  • Bisphosphonates are structurally similar to pyrophosphates and are incorporated into the bone matrix.
  • They decrease bone resorption by impairing osteoclast function.
  • Bisphosphonates concentrate at sites of active remodeling. They remain in the matrix until the bone is remodeled. Then, they are released in the acid environment of the resorption lacunae and induce apoptosis in osteoclasts.
  • Osteoclasts internalize bisphosphonates as they are released along with calcium from the bone surface and then reduces osteoclast activity by
    • Promoting apoptosis of osteoclasts
    • Disrupting the cytoskeleton and ruffled border of osteoclasts
    • Inhibiting the differentiation of osteoclasts
  • The bisphosphonates approved for the treatment of osteoporosis are alendronate, risedronate, ibandronate, and zoledronate

Alendronate and risedronate can be administered daily or weekly with different dosages. Ibandronate can be administered daily, weekly or quarterly and Zoledronate is administered annually.

Indications for bisphosphonates :-

  • Osteoporosis
  • Paget’s disease
  • Hypercalcemia of malignancy
  • Osteolytic bone metastasis

Administration :-

Bisphosphonates are not recommended to be administered with food to minimise esophageal irritation.

Oral bisphosphonates have very limited bioavailability (<1-10%). Bisphosphonates are recommended to be administered after an overnight fast with a full glass of water at least 30 minutes before breakfast. Remaining upright for 30 minutes after dosing and proton pump inhibitors at bedtime can decrease the symptoms

Adverse Effects:

  • Osteonecrosis of the jaw is associated with the use of bisphosphonates 
  • Atypical femur fracture - occurs in the subtrochanteric femoral region or along the shaft distal to the lesser trochanter.

questions.text: Which of the following is an important sign of antemortem drowning:
questions.solution:
An important sign of antemortem drowning is cadaveric spasm which manifests as weed, grass ,sticks etc. floating in the water being firmly grasped in the hands. When present, it is an important sign suggesting that the victim struggled for existence while in water.

 Features like emphysema aquosum, froth in the air passages, hemorrhage into the middle ears, and subpleural hemorrhages are seen in cases of drowning. Overinflation of the lungs in drowning is known as emphysema aquosum. The edema fluid in the bronchi blocks the passive collapse that normally occurs at death, holding the lungs in the inspiratory position. In drowning this may be sufficient to mark the lateral surfaces of the lungs with the impression of the ribs, leaving visible and palpable grooves after removal of the organs from the thorax. This is a valuable positive sign of drowning to be gained at autopsy.

Autopsy findings in drowning:

  • Froth in the air passages - The most useful autopsy sign in drowning. It consists of a proteinaceous exudate and surfactant mixed with the water of the drowning medium.
  • Waterlogging of the lung - Frothy fluid will exude from the bronchi when the lung is squeezed and from the cut surfaces when they are sectioned with a knife. But, absence of waterlogging by no means excludes true drowning (e.g. dry drowning).
  • Emphysema aqueosum - Overinflation of the lungs.
  • Paltauf’s spots - Subpleural haemorrhages that probably reflect haemolysis within intra-alveolar haemorrhages, and have been described in 50–60% of drownings.
  • Dilation of right heart and great veins - This is a very subjective and non-specific finding.
  • Foreign material in stomach - The stomach may contain watery fluid or even foreign material from the water, such as silt, weed or sand. This is also not a finding which can diagnose drowning.
  • Haemorrhage into the middle ears and into the temporal bone - This has been postulated as a positive sign of drowning, it is a non-specific finding.
  • Presence of fluid in the middle ear or paranasal sinuses - Also not a reliable diagnostic sign of drowning.

Note - Thus, the autopsy findings in drowning are mostly nonspecific and none give conclusive evidence of drowning. The most useful one is froth in the air passages.

Related Pearl: Differentiating features between Antemortem amd Postmortem drowning

       Antemortem drowning       Postmortem drowning
Foam/froth at nostrils or mouth Not present
Cadaveric spasm Not present
Lungs usually are voluminous, bulky, water-logged and over-inflated ,called as emphysema aquosum. Passive collection of water  in the lungs without any formation of columns of froth,has been called as oedema aquosum.
Presence of foam, fluid, debris, weeds, vegetation, etc. in the bronchi and bronchioles. Foreign matter may passively find access only to the upper respiratory passage.
Demonstration of diatoms in the lungs, liver, brain, bone marrow, etc. Diatoms may reach the lungs but not to the distant organs because of absence of circulation.
Stomach may contain water and foreign material like sand, weed, dirt etc which may be swallowed while struggling for life. Water could enter the stomach. However, quantity of foreign matter may become the decisive issue.

questions.text: Most common site of origin for nasopharyngeal carcinoma is
questions.solution:
Commonest site of origin for nasopharyngeal carcinoma is the fossa of Rosenmüller.

  • Epstein–Barr Virus (EBV) is closely associated with nasopharyngeal cancer.
  • EB virus has two important antigens: Viral capsid antigen (VCA) and Early antigen (EA).
  • IgA antibodies against both EA and VCA should be done for screening of patients for nasopharyngeal cancer.

Presenting symptoms and signs of nasopharyngeal cancer in order of frequency are:

  • Cervical lymphadenopathy (most common) (60–90%)
  • Hearing loss
  • Nasal obstruction
  • Epistaxis
  • Cranial nerve palsies -Cranial nerves V and VI are the most commonly involved among all the cranial nerves. 
  • Headache
  • Earache
  • Neck pain
  • Weight loss

Trotter’s Triad:

  1. Conductive hearing loss
  2. Immobility of homolateral soft palate
  3. Trigeminal neuralgia

Pathology:

 Gross image would either be ulcerative or proliferative or infiltrative, cystic presentation is not seen. Microscopy would reveal squamous cell carcinoma or anaplastic variety and ectodermal features are seen. 

Radiotherapy is the treatment of choice for nasopharyngeal cancer.

  • Stage I and II are treated by radiotherapy alone.
  • Stage III and IV require concomitant radiation and chemotherapy or radiation followed by chemotherapy
  • Radical neck dissection can be done in case of recurrent or residual disease.

questions.text: A 24-year-old patient with history of hepatitis and behavioral changes is known to have an inborn error of metabolism. Ocular examination of this patient shows the following finding. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The image shows Kayser–Fleisher ring, which is seen in Wilson’s disease.  

Kayser-Fleischer ring (KF) Ring:

  • KF ring is a golden-brown ring formed due to the deposition of copper in Descemet’s membrane of the cornea
  • Characteristically observed in Wilson's disease but is not pathognomonic
  • Does not interfere with vision
  • Present in almost all patients of Wilson's disease with neurological/psychiatric symptoms
  • Present only in 30–50% of patients diagnosed in the hepatic or presymptomatic state, therefore the absence of KF rings does not exclude the diagnosis of Wilson's disease.

Wilsons disease:

The autosomal-recessive disease is caused by mutations in the ATP7B gene, which encodes a membrane-bound, copper-transporting ATPase.

Clinical symptoms:

  • Hepatitis and cirrhosis
  • Behavioral disturbances
  • Wing beating tremor
  • Ophthalmic characteristics:
    • Deposition of copper in the posterior capsule of the lens resulting in sunflower cataract
    • KF ring 

Diagnosis:

    • Presence of KF rings
    • Decreased serum ceruloplasmin (copper-containing enzyme/ferroxidase) levels
    • Measured hepatic copper levels in liver biopsy
    • Increased 24-hour urine copper excretion

The gold standard for diagnosis: Liver biopsy with quantitative copper assays

Treatment: Trientine and Zinc is the first choice of a drug regimen to be used for treating mild hepatic decompensation in Wilson’s disease.

Recommended drugs in Wilsons disease:

Disease Status First Choice Second Choice
Initial    

Hepatitis or Cirrhosis without decompensation

 Zinc Trientine
Hepatic decompensation    
Mild Trientine and Zinc Penicillamine and Zinc
Moderate Trientine and Zinc Hepatic transplantation
Severe Hepatic Transplantation Trientine and Zinc
Initial neurological/Psychiatric Tetrathiomolybdate and Zinc Zinc
Maintenance Zinc Trientine
Presymptomatic Zinc Trientine

questions.text: The COPRA was instated in India, in 1986. This legislation is related to ______
questions.solution:
Consumer Protection Act or COPRA was instituted in 1986 and deals with consumer rights.

  • It recognizes six rights of the consumers, which are
    • Right to safety
    • Right to be informed
    • Right to be heard
    • Right to choose
    • Right to seek redressal
    • Right to consumer education

questions.text: Example of multiphasic screening is _____

choices.text: Chest X-ray for TB in large populations
Pap smear in women above 40 years
Random blood sugar during antenatal visits

questions.solution:
Example of multiphasic screening is annual health checkups.

Multiphasic screening is the application of two or more screening tests in combination to a large number of people at one time.

High-risk or selective screening is done on high-risk groups example- MRI screening of breast done annually in 25-year old women with BRCA 1, BRCA 2 mutations in first degree relative .

Pap smears screening as per American Cancer Society (ACS) should start at age 21. Women aged <21 years should not be screened regardless of the age of sexual initiation or other risk factors. 

Mass screening is a screening of a whole or large population like using chest X-ray for TB screening in large populations. It is done for diseases with high prevalence.

questions.text: Which of the following items are disposed of in the yellow bag?
questions.solution:
Blood bags are disposed of in the yellow bag.

Gloves are disposed of in the red bag.

Sharps are disposed of in the white container.

Urine bags are disposed of in the red bag.

However, it may be disposed of in a municipal landfill, if the toxic metals in incineration ash are within the regulatory quantities as defined under the Hazardous Waste (Management and Handling and Transboundary Movement) Rules, 2008 as amended from time to time.

questions.text: A patient presented with the complaints of chest pain. Which among the following is the best investigation to diagnose MI within 2-4 hours?
questions.solution:
Measurement of Troponin is the best investigation to diagnose MI within 2-4 hours.

Troponin T and Troponin I

  • These are the proteins that mediate calcium-mediated contraction of the cardiac and the skeletal muscles.
  • They are highly specific for MI.
  • Troponins will remain elevated longer than creatine kinase (CK), for up to 14 days.

Creatine phosphokinase (CK): 

  • CK rises within 4–8 h and generally returns to normal by 48–72 h. However, CK is non-specific, as it may be elevated with skeletal muscle disease or trauma, including intramuscular injection. The MB isoenzyme of CK (CK-MB) is not significantly found in the extracardiac tissue, and is more specific.

Lactate dehydrogenase (LDH)

  • Normally, serum levels of LDH2 is greater than those of LDH1; but, in MI, LDH1 is more than LDH2. This is called flipping of the LDH ratio.
  • Current recommendations suggest that LDH no longer has a role in the diagnosis of MI.

Related Pearl: Cardiac Biomarkers

Cardiac biomarker

Rise

Peak

Return to baseline

CK-MB

2-4 hours

24 hours

48-72 hours

Troponin T and I

2-4 hours

Troponin T 24-48 hours

Troponin I- max at 24 hours 

7-10 days

LDH

24 hours

SGOT

questions.text: A 30-year-old female with a past medical history of generalized seizures controlled with phenytoin therapy. She had mild pallor on physical examination. Lab values reveal Hb -  9.8 g/dl, MCV - 106 fL, Platelets - 1,80,000/cu.mm, leukocytes - 7800/cu.mm. Which of the following supplementations could have prevented this anemia?
questions.solution:
This patient has mild megaloblastic anemia (high MCV), probably due to chronic phenytoin therapy. Some anti-epileptic drugs like phenytoin, phenobarbital can cause megaloblastic anemia by impairing absorption of folate in the small intestine. Folic acid supplementation can prevent this condition.

Related Pearl: Difference between B12 and Folic acid Deficiency

questions.text: A patient comes with a blood pressure of 160/100 mmHg and left-sided facial paralysis and weakness since 1 hour. Her CT appears normal. What would be your next step?
questions.solution:
Sudden onset hemiparesis with apparently normal CT indicates ischemic stroke in this patient.

Intravenous thrombolysis (alteplase: 0.9 mg/kg ) should be immediately administered to patients with ischemic stroke who arrive in window period (within 3/4.5 hours of symptom onset).

Related Pearl: Indications and Contraindications of thrombolysis in Ischemic Stroke

Indications for thrombolysis in stroke 

  • Clinical diagnosis of stroke
  • Onset of symptoms to time of drug administration <3 hours/4.5 hours
  • Age ≥ 18 years
  • CT scan showing no haemorrhage or edema of >1/3rd of the MCA territory 

Contraindications of thrombolysis in stroke 

  • Sustained BP >185/110 mmHg despite treatment
  • Bleeding diathesis
  • Recent head injury or Intracerebral hemorrhage
  • Major surgery in preceding 14 days
  • Minor stroke symptoms
  • Gastrointestinal bleeding in preceding 21 days
  • Recent myocardial infarction

questions.text: Which of the following is the gold standard investigation for diagnosis of COVID-19?

choices.text: Reverse transcription - polymerase chain reaction test

questions.solution:
The gold standard for the diagnosis of Covid-19 is the identification of viral genome targets in the respiratory tract materials by reverse transcriptase polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) during the first week of symptoms.

RT-PCR: This method involves the reverse transcription of the genetic material of the virus (RNA) to complementary DNA (cDNA), followed by amplification of some regions of the cDNA.

Rapid antigen test (RAT): Antigen-based assays are used as point-of-care tests for early detection of SARS-CoV-2. They are used at the field level for early detection of infection and quick containment. Most of such tests have relatively moderate sensitivity but high specificity. They are used for diagnosis along with RT-PCR. 

Antibody testing: Antibodies of IgA, IgM, and IgG isotypes specific to different virus proteins are detected by enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA) or chemiluminescence immunoassays (CLIA). CLIA is more sensitive compared to ELISA.

questions.text: A 3-year child is brought to the pediatrician for the evaluation of the lateral neck mass. On examination, a painless, soft, fluctuating mass is found in the lateral side of the neck as shown in the image. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A soft, painless, fluctuating mass found in the posterior part of the neck in a child, is most likely to be a cystic hygroma.

Cystic hygroma is a lymph filled sac that results from the obstruction of the lymph vessels during their development. It is most commonly present in the posterior triangle of the neck. The mass may be apparent at birth or may appear in early childhood due to the increased accumulation of lymph. Since the sac is filled with lymph, it is soft, fluctuating, and brilliantly transilluminant.

Treatment:

  • Lymphangiomas are treated by surgical excision and image-guided sclerotherapy.
  • Initially, surgical excision is done to safely remove the lymphatic malformation without causing any damage to the adjacent vital tissues such as blood vessels, nerves, or muscles.
  • For large tumors and the tumors that extend to the base of the tongue or floor of the mouth, combined sclerotherapy and surgical resection are done.
  • If there is any residual lymphatic malformation after the treatment, then a conservative excision or unroofing of the cyst is done. It may be combined with sclerosing therapy or repeated partial excisions.

Note: The terms lymphangioma and cystic hygromas are older terms. They are now called lymphatic malformations.

Option B: A thyroglossal duct cyst is a congenital midline neck swelling that typically presents during childhood often noticed after an upper respiratory infection. Classically the cyst moves upwards on swallowing and on tongue protrusion. This indicates attachment to the hyoid bone and the swelling is smooth, soft, fluctuant (cystic), non-tender, mobile, and shows transillumination.

Option C : Ranula is a transilluminant mucocele. It is also known as "frog's belly", as it resembles the vocal sacs of a frog. It occurs due to an obstruction in the sublingual salivary gland. A ranula usually presents as a large, tense, bluish swelling on the floor of the mouth to one side on the midline. If the obstruction happens in the ducts of minor salivary glands such as labial or buccal, it is termed mucocele.

Option D: Cervical lymphadenopathy is seen in children with infections of the parotid and upper respiratory tract infections. On palpation, they are firm and non-fluctuant.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common type of tracheo-esophageal fistula?
questions.solution:
The type C Tracheo-esophageal fistula (TEF), is the most common type.

TEF is an abnormal communication between Esophagus and Trachea.

Type C is most common - it has proximal esophageal atresia and distal TEF (the proximal blind pouch ends at the distance of one or two vertebral bodies from the distal TEF)

Types and frequency of TEF (Gross classification)

  • Type A  (~7%): Pure esophageal atresia. A long gap between the two esophageal blind pouches. No fistula.
  • Type B (2-3%): The upper esophageal pouch abnormally connects to the trachea (proximal TEF). The lower esophageal pouch ends blindly.
  • Type C (~86%): The lower esophageal pouch abnormally connects to the trachea (distal TEF). The upper esophageal pouch ends blindly.
  • Type D (<1%): Both the upper and lower esophageal pouch have an abnormal connection with the trachea (both proximal and distal TEF), in two separate locations.
  • Type E (4%):  No esophageal atresia. Abnormal connection between the esophagus and the trachea present (H-type TEF). 
  • Type F (<1%): Congenital esophageal stenosis. No fistula. 

TEF is associated with VACTERL (vertebral, anorectal, cardiac, tracheal, esophageal, renal, and limb) anomalies.

Related Pearl: Types of Tracheo-esophageal Fistula/Esophageal Atresia

Abbreviations:

  • EA: Esophageal atresia
  • TEF: Tracheoesophageal Fistula

questions.text: A patient is confused, opens his eyes on painful stimuli,  flexes one limb on painful stimuli, and can localize the stimulus with the other limb. His Glasgow Coma Score is ________
questions.solution:
The GCS in this patient is 11.

Score for verbal response: 4, because he is confused

Score for eye-opening: 2, because his eyes are opening to painful stimulus only.

Score for best motor response: 5, because he can localize pain

Therefore, the GCS score is (4+2+5) = 11.

Related Pearl: Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS)

GCS Score

  • 13-15 represent mild brain injury
  • 9-12 represent moderate brain injury
  • scores ≤8 represent severe brain injury 

Head Injury Severity: Clinical classification 

Eyes Opening

 Score
Spontaneously 4
To verbal command 3
To painful stimulus 2
Do not open 1

Non-testable

 NT

 

Verbal response Score
Normal-oriented conversation 5
Confused 4
Inappropriate words only 3
Sounds only 2
No sounds 1

Non-testable

 NT

 

Motor Response Score
Obeys commands 6
Localizes to pain 5
Withdrawal/flexion 4
Abnormal flexion/Decorticate posturing  3
Extension/Decerebrate posturing  2
No motor response 1

Non-testable

 NT

Minimum value: 3

Maximum value: 15

  • The motor score, is the best predictor of neurological outcome.
  • If an area cannot be assessed, no numerical score is given for that region, and it is considered “non-testable." (NT)
  • In case of endotracheal intubation or tracheostomy, the verbal component of the score is denoted as NT.

 

NOTE: 

A new parameter, "pupil reactivity score" has been added to GCS, and now, it is referred to as GCS-P.

P stands for "Pupils unreactive to light"

Pupils Unreactive to light Score
Both pupils 2
One pupil 1 
Neither  0

The pupillary score is subtracted from the GCS score to give the final value. Therefore, the range of GCS-P is 1–15.

questions.text: A 34 year old construction worker with no comorbidities presents with exertional pain in both forearms and hands. He smokes 1 pack of cigarettes per day. On examination, brachial pulses are palpable but radial and ulnar pulses are feeble. Image  of his hand is shown. Angiography of his upper extremity shows smooth tapering segmental lesions in the distal arterial vessels. Which of the following treatments has the greatest chances of success?
questions.solution:
This is a classical clinical scenario of thromboangiitis obliterans. There is no specific treatment except abstinence from tobacco.

Key points in the question:

  • Male < 40years
  • Smoker
  • Involvement of upper extremity
  • Raynauds phenomenon

Thromboangiitis Obliterans (Buerger’s disease):

  • An inflammatory occlusive vascular disorder involving small and medium-sized arteries and veins in the distal upper and lower extremities.
  • Most common in men <40 years of age.
  • Although the cause of thromboangiitis obliterans is not known, there is a definite relationship to cigarette smoking in patients with this disorder.
  • MRA, CTA, and conventional arteriography show smooth, tapering segmental lesions in the distal vessels with collateral vessels at sites of vascular occlusion.
  • There is no specific treatment except abstention from tobacco.
  • The prognosis is worse in individuals who continue to smoke, but results are discouraging even in those who stop smoking.
  • Antibiotics may be useful.
  • Anticoagulants and glucocorticoids are not helpful.
  • If these measures fail, amputation may be required.

No Smoking Day is observed every year on the second Wednesday of March. The aim of the campaign is to encourage people over the world to quit smoking. The main purpose of this day is to spread awareness about the harmful health effects of tobacco consumption through cigarette and other modes.

questions.text: The partogram of a 28 year old G2P1 is shown below. What is the next step in management?
questions.solution:
The above partogram shows a case of obstructed labour and management is a caesarean section.

There is a secondary arrest of dilatation for >2 hours and arrest of descent for >1 hour. The patient has adequate uterine contractions as shown. The amniotic fluid is stained with meconium and there is fall in fetal heart rate which indicates that the baby is in distress.

There is no place for wait and watch and use of oxytocin to stimulate uterine contractions in obstructed labor.

 

The WHO partograph is a repeatedly tested topic in the NBE and Central Institute exams.

Related Pearl: Partograph

Partograph types:

WHO Modified Partograph (2000)

  • No latent phase
  • Vaginal examination: This should be done no less than every 4 hours to assess cervical dilatation, descent of the fetal head, and moulding of skull bones. More frequent examination is only undertaken if indicated.
  • Charting starts at 4 cm of cervical dilation.
  • Colour of liquor mentioned as C-clear, B-blood stained, M-meconium stained.
  • Moulding mentioned:
    • bones are separated and sutures can be easily felt - (0)
    • bones touching (1+)
    • bones overlapping but can be reduced(2+)
    • bones severely overlapping and irreducible ( 3+).
  • Alert line reflects the average rate of cervical dilation of the slowest quintile of term primigravidas, if dilation slows or ceases, the partograph plot will cross the alert line.
  • Alert line: at 4 cm dilation and expected dilation of 1 cm/hour.
  • Action line is 2–4 hours after the alert line, which prompts interventions to accelerate labor or perform cesarean delivery.
  • Higher rates of perinatal mortality are associated with delays of 4 hours or more after the alert line.
  • Contractions measured for a span of 10 min (duration noted) and measured every 30 min (1 square = half hour).
  • Pulse: record every 30 minutes and mark with a dot (•).
  • Blood pressure: record every 4 hours and mark with arrows, unless the patient has a hypertensive disorder or pre-eclampsia, in which case record every 30 minutes.
  • Temperature: record every 4 hours.

WHO Composite Partograph: It is same as modified except for it has latent phase and charting done at 3 cm.

WHO Simplified Partograph: WHO further modified the partograph for use by skilled attendants in health centers. This simplified partograph is colour coded.

  • The area to the left of the alert line in the cervicograph is coloured green, representing normal progress.
  • The area to the right of the action line is coloured red, indicating dangerously slow progress in labour.
  • The area in between the alert and action line is coloured amber, indicating the need for greater vigilance.

questions.text: A 55-year-old lady comes with abnormal uterine bleeding. Hysterectomy was performed and the following specimen was  retrieved. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The specimen is of a Leiomyoma.

The uterine body / corpus is enlarged and deformed. The cut surface shows multiple nodules, well-circumscribed, firm, white-greyish with a whorled appearance formed by the intersecting bundles of brown muscle fibers and white fibrous tissue. Leiomyomas can also present bleeding areas, cystic degeneration and calcifications. The uterine cavity is compressed.

Menstrual symptoms of fibroid includes:

  • Menorrhagia, polymenorrhoea, metrorrhagia, continuous or postmenopausal bleeding
  • Dysmenorrhea
  • Infertility, recurrent abortions
  • Pain
  • Pressure symptoms
  • Abdominal lump
  • Vaginal discharge

Drugs to reduce the size of the fibroid:

  • Antiprogesterone – Mifepristone/RU-486
  • Danazol (Usually not used due to androgenic side effects)
  • GnRH 
    • Agonists – goserelin, leuprorelin, nafarelin, busereli
    • Antagonists – cetrorelix, ganirelix
  • Selective progesterone receptor modulator (SPRM’s) – Ulipristal, Asoprisnil

Other medical methods to treat fibroids include:

  • Levonorgestrel IUD- controls bleeding effectively
  • Combined oral contraceptives
  • DMPA
  • Tranexamic acid
  • Iron therapy for anemia
  • Selective estrogen-receptor modulators (SERMs) like tibolone and raloxifene are used as add-back therapy along with GnRH treatment. They reduce associated vasomotor symptoms and bone loss.

Radiological interventions for fibroids:

  • Uterine artery Embolization - Angiographic interventional procedure where polyvinyl alcohol microspheres are introduced into both uterine arteries, producing ischemia and necrosis of the fibroid.
  • Magnetic Resonance guided Focused Ultrasound - Ultrasound energy is focused to cause coagulative necrosis in selected fibroids.

Related Pearl: Secondary changes and complications in fibromyomas

  • Hyaline change, cystic degeneration and atrophy

  • Calcareous degeneration, osseous degeneration

  • Red degeneration

  • Sarcomatous change

  • Torsion, hemorrhage

  • Infection/ ulceration, particularly in the dependent part of a submucous polyp

  • Inversion of the uterus

  • Endometrial carcinoma associated with fibromyoma

  • Endometrial and myohyperplasia

  • Accompanying adenomyosis

  • Parasitic fibroid

questions.text: Amsel’s criteria for diagnosis of bacterial vaginosis include all except _______
questions.solution:
Abundant polymorphs is not included in Amsel’s criteria.

Amsel’s criteria is used for diagnosis of bacterial vaginosis which includes

  • Homogenous vaginal discharge
  • Vaginal pH > 4.5
  • Amine like odour on adding KOH (Whiff test positive)
  • Clue cells (>20% of cells)

At least three of the four criteria should be present to confirm the diagnosis.

Bacterial vaginosis, in which Gardnerella vaginalis is the main causative agent, presents with a vaginal discharge without pruritis. Discharge is homogenous, creamy/greyish white, with fishy odor, and adherent to the vaginal wall

On microscopy, there is no abundance of polymorphs in a case of bacterial vaginosis as it is just an alteration of flora and not an inflammation.

  • The diagnosis is based on wet smear and culture.
  • The smear reveals clean background with few inflammatory cells and other organ­isms, but scanty lactobacilli. Many epithelial cells present a granular cytoplasm caused by small gram-negative bacilli adhering on their surface, the so-called clue cells. Gram stain is 90% sensitive.

Metronidazole, an antibiotic with activity against anaerobes but poor activity against lactobacilli, is the drug of choice for the treatment of BV. A dose of 500 mg administered orally twice a day for 7 days should be used or the same can be given as gel, if available.

 

 

Related Pearl: Vaginal infections

  Bacterial vaginosis Trichomonas vaginalis

Candida albicans
Causative organism  Altered vaginal flora- increased concentration of Gardnerella vaginalis Trichomas vaginalis-parasitic infection Fungal infection
Etiology Increased vaginal pH Sexually transmitted Decreased immunity
Sexual trans-mission No Yes No
Discharge Fishy, thin, yellow Frothy, green Curdy, white
Symptoms Fishy odor, no itching Itching and burning Itching, burning
pH >4.5 >4.5 <4.5
Speculum No vaginal epithelium inflammation Strawberry cervix Inflamed-epithelium
KOH Positive Whiff test Whiff test can be positive. Pseudohyphae seen.
Wet mount Clue cells. No WBCs seen Motile trichomaonads, WBCs seen WBCs seen
Treatment Metronidazole or Clindamycin Metronidazole, treat partner also Oral or vaginal azole, no need to treat partner.

questions.text: A healthy child is brought to the pediatrician for a routine check-up. The child comes in with a toy in her hand and readily shares it with the doctor. She is able to say her name. Her mother says she does most of her activities with her right hand now. If she is given a paper and pen, which of the following will she be able to do?
questions.solution:
This child who is able to say her name, shares toys, and has developed handedness is around three years of age and she will be able to copy a circle.

Developmental milestones at the age of three:

Social and Emotional:

These children usually copy adults and friends, engage in cooperative play, show affection for friends and concern for crying friends without prompts, understand the concept of ownership but are able to share toys, show a wide range of emotions, and may get upset with changes in routine easily.

Language and Communication:

Follow instructions with two/three steps, can name most things around them, understand prepositions, use pronouns, name friends and make a simple conversation with two sentences.

Cognitive:

Copy a circle with a crayon, turn book pages one at a time, build towers with six or more blocks, screw and unscrew jars/lids and can do puzzles with four or fewer pieces

Motor:

Climb well, run easily, pedal a tricycle and walk up and down stairs with one foot on each step

 

Related Pearl: Important developmental milestones at various ages

Developmental Milestones
At 1 year
  • Motor: Walks with support
  • Adaptive: Mature pincer grasp
  • Language: Speaks a few words
  • Social: Plays simple ball game
  • Domestic mimicry at 18 months
At 2 years
  • Motor: Walks up and downstairs, one step at a time
  • Adaptive: Makes a tower of 6 blocks 
  • Language: Simple sentences, a vocabulary of 50-100 words, uses pronouns at 2.5 yrs
  • Social: Asks for food and starts toilet training, listens to stories
At 3 years
  • Motor: Rides tricycle
  • Adaptive: Makes a tower of 9 blocks, handedness is established
  • Language: Knows full name, age, gender
  • Social: Plays simple games and engages in parallel play with other children
At 4 years
  • Motor: Hops
  • Adaptive: Draws square and constructs a bridge with blocks
  • Language: Tells stories
  • Social: Goes to the toilet alone
At 5 years
  • Motor: Skips
  • Adaptive: Draws a triangle
  • Language: Asks the meaning of words, names 4 colors
  • Social: Dresses and undresses

questions.text: Tardy ulnar nerve palsy is seen in which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Tardy ulnar nerve palsy is seen in cubitus valgus. 

Cubitus valgus deformity can occur as a complication of fracture of lateral condyle of the humerus.

Fracture of lateral condyle of humerus occurs when the patient falls on the hand with the elbow extended and forced into varus (forearm pushed medially with respect to elbow). A large fragment of bone including the lateral condyle breaks off and is pulled away by the attached wrist extensors. The normal 3-point bony relationship at the elbow is lost. 

It is a Salter-Harris type IV injury. As it is an intra-articular fracture, it is surgically managed by open reduction and internal fixation. 

Common complications include stiffness of elbow, nonunion and cubitus valgus deformity. This deformity can lead to chronic injury to the ulnar nerve (tardy ulnar palsy). Friction neuritis of the ulnar nerve occurs as it moves over the medial epicondyle in cubitus valgus leading to late ulnar nerve palsy.

questions.text: The characteristic appearance of oesophagus on barium swallow, as shown in the image below,  is seen in which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
The corkscrew appearance of the esophagus is seen in diffuse esophageal spasm.

  • Diffuse/distal esophageal spasm (DES) is a motility disorder of the esophagus.
  • On barium swallow, DES may appear as a corkscrew or rosary bead esophagus, but this is uncommon.
  • Manometry is the gold-standard diagnostic test.

Achalasia is a primary esophageal motility disorder characterised by the absence of esophageal peristalsis and impaired relaxation of the lower esophageal sphincter (LES) in response to swallowing.

In achalasia single contrast esophagogram shows, dilatation of the esophagus with a bird beak deformity near the gastroesophageal junction.

In esophageal carcinoma barium study will show irregular narrowing, mucosal destruction and shouldered margins.

Double-contrast esophagram shows a large, flat ulceration (arrow) in the distal esophagus in a patient with CMV esophagitis.

questions.text: A 7-year-old child presented with complaints of bed-wetting almost twice a week for the past 1 year. A detailed investigation was done to rule out the organic cause. What should be the treatment plan for this child?

choices.text: Bladder training (with reward for delaying micturition during daytime)
Bell and pad based classical conditioning

questions.solution:
The clinical features are suggestive of nocturnal enuresis. Bell and pad based classical conditioning is the most effective treatment.

Nocturnal enuresis refers to the occurrence of involuntary urination at night after 5 years of age. It may be a normal phenomenon in children up to 5 years of age.

Treatment for nocturnal enuresis may include either behavioural therapy, pharmacotherapy, or psychotherapy.

Behavioural therapy:

  • Classic conditioning with the bell (or buzzer) and pad (alarm) apparatus is the most effective treatment for enuresis.
  • Dryness is achieved in 50% of the cases.
  • Bladder training with encouragement or reward for delaying micturition for increasing times during waking hours is useful but considered as an inferior to bell and pad.

Pharmacotherapy:

  • Medications should be considered if behavioural therapy has failed, and if enuresis is causing impairment in social, family, and school function.
  • Desmopressin (an antidiuretic) and Reboxetine (norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor) are commonly used drugs. Reboxetine is considered as a safer alternative to imipramine.

Psychotherapy:

  • It is indicated in cases with chronic enuresis, to deal with any coexisting psy­chiatric problems and the emotional and family difficulties.

questions.text: The best type of anesthesia for pre eclampsia is:
questions.solution:
Continuous epidural anesthesia is the first choice for most patients with preeclampsia during labor, vaginal delivery, and cesarean section.

Pre-eclampsia patients have a risk of severe airway edema, which makes intubation difficult. Thus continuous epidural anesthesia is advantageous as it avoids the need for intubation. Besides, continuous epidural anesthesia can improve uteroplacental perfusion and also decrease catecholamine secretion.

But one major prerequisite for regional anesthesia in preeclamptic patients is normal platelet count and normal coagulation. Coagulopathy is a contraindication for regional anesthesia.Minimal platelet count for regional anesthesia is 100,000/μL, but some cases can be taken up with a platelet count as low as 70,000/μL.

General anesthesia is indicated in patients with coagulopathy and in severe pre-eclampsia with complications. Spinal anesthesia can be given in mild pre-eclampsia but hypotension associated with spinal anesthesia limits its use in moderate to severe pre-eclampsia.

questions.text: The most common cutaneous manifestation in systemic lupus erythematosus is ________
questions.solution:
The most common cutaneous manifestation of Systemic Lupus Erythematosus is photosensitivity.

In decreasing order, the cutaneous manifestations in SLE are:

  • Photosensitivity (63%)
  • Raynaud's Phenomenon (60%)
  • Malar Rash (51%)
  • Chronic Urticaria >36 hrs (44%)
  • Non-scarring Alopecia (40%)
  • Mouth Ulceration (31%)

Related Pearl: Antibodies in Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE)

Antibody Clinical utility
Antinuclear antibodies Best screening test 
Anti-Sm Most specific for SLE
Anti-dsDNA

High titers correlate with disease severity

Increases the risk of nephritis
Anti-Ro(SS-A)

Predisposes to subacute cutaneous lupus, neonatal lupus with congenital heart blocks.

Decreases the risk of nephritis
Anti-La(SS-B) Decreases the risk of nephritis
Antineuronal  Associated with CNS lupus
Antiribosomal P Associated with psychosis or depression in CNS lupus
Anti-RNP High titers are diagnostic of mixed connective tissue disease
Antihistone Associated with drug-induced lupus

questions.text: Which of the following are causes of high RAIU (radioactive iodine uptake)?
questions.solution:
All three are classical examples of high RAIU.

Radioactive Iodine Scan:

  • Nonpregnant, hyperthyroid patients with physical examination suggesting nodular thyroid disease, radioactive iodine should be the initial test to determine the aetiology of hyperthyroidism.
  • Pregnancy and breastfeeding are absolute contraindications to radionuclide imaging.
  • Hyperthyroidism with a high (or normal) radioiodine uptake indicates de-novo synthesis of the hormone.
  • Hyperthyroidism with a low (nearly absent) radioiodine uptake indicates either inflammation and destruction of thyroid tissue with release of preformed hormone into the circulation or an extrathyroidal source of thyroid hormone, such as in patients with factitious thyrotoxicosis and in patients with struma ovari.

Subacute thyroiditis shows low uptake of radioactive iodine as it involves destruction and inflammation of the thyroid follicles, which also accounts for the thyrotoxic symptoms due to exocytosis of the hormone.

Related Pearl: Radioiodine uptake of thyroid gland

Increased Hormone Synthesis (Increased RAIU) Release of Preformed Hormone (Decreased RAIU)
  • Graves’ disease
  • Toxic multinodular goiter
  • Toxic adenoma
  • Drug induced—amiodarone
  • Iodine
  • Thyroid cancer
  • Hydatidiform mole
  • TSH-secreting pituitary adenoma
  • Thyroiditis—acute phase of Hashimoto’s thyroiditis, subacute thyroiditis
  • Factitious (iatrogenic) thyrotoxicosis
  • Struma ovarii
  • Hamburger thyrotoxicosis 
  • Subacute/ Dequervain thyroiditis
  • Metastatic follicular thyroid carcinoma
  • Radiation thyroiditis
